0.0             EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This report presents the transportation impact analysis conducted for the proposed Berkeley Aquatic Park
Master Plan in Berkeley, California. The Project site is currently occupied by office/R&D space and a rock/soil
distribution center and will be converted into approximately 475,000 square feet of R&D space. The Project
site is located in the block bounded by Addison Street to the north, railroad tracks to the east, Bancroft Way
to the south, and Bolivar Drive to the west.

This analysis evaluates the impacts of the proposed Project on traffic operations under Pipeline and
Cumulative (2040) conditions. This report also includes a discussion of access, circulation and parking for
the project site.



 0.1            STUDY AREA

This study focuses on the operations of the following 15 intersections in the vicinity of the site during the
weekday morning (7:00-9:00 AM) and evening (4:00-6:00 PM) peak hours:

 1.       Gilman Street/I-80 Westbound Ramps/West          8.    Fourth Street/Hearst Avenue
          Frontage Road                                    9.    Fourth Street/Addison Street
 2.       Gilman Street/I-80 Eastbound Ramps/              10.   Fourth Street/Bancroft way
          Eastshore Highway                                11.   Sixth Street/Hearst Avenue
 3.       Bolivar Drive/Addison Street                     12.   Sixth Street/University Avenue
 4.       Bolivar Drive/Bancroft Way                       13.   Sixth Street/Bancroft Way
 5.       Second Street/Hearst Avenue                      14.   Seventh Street/Dwight Way
 6.       Second Street/I-80 Eastbound Off-Ramp            15.   San Pablo Avenue/University Avenue
 7.       Second Street/Addison Street


 0.2            EXISITING CONDITIONS

Based on traffic data collected in 2016 and 2017, all study intersections operate at LOS D or better during
both AM and PM peak hours, except the following:

           The side-street stop-controlled Gilman Street/I-80 Ramps intersections (#1 and #2) operate at LOS
            F during both AM and PM peak hours
           The signalized San Pablo Avenue/University Avenue intersection (#15) operates at LOS E during the
            PM peak hour.




                                                                                                             3
               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017




 0.3         PROJECT TRANSPORTATION CHARACTERISCTIS

It is estimated that the proposed project would generate about 379 AM and 363 PM net new peak-hour
trips.



 0.4         PIPELINE CONDITIONS

The addition of project traffic as compared to the Pipeline No Project condition is expected to result in the
following significant impacts:


Impact 1 – The Project would add more than 10 peak hour trips to the southbound approach (critical
approach) at the Gilman Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#1B), would contribute to LOS F
operations on the southbound approach at the intersection during both AM and PM peak hours, and would
meet the California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant under the Pipeline Plus Project scenario, causing a
significant impact based on City of Berkeley thresholds.

         Mitigation Measure 1: The impact can be mitigated by implementing the planned improvements
         at the I-80 Gilman Street interchange, which would consist of two roundabouts. With
         implementation of this mitigation measure, this impact would be reduced to a less-than-significant
         level. The Project shall contribute a fair share to the design and implementation of these
         improvements, which is estimated to be about two percent. It is estimated that this impact would
         be triggered and the mitigation measure would need to be implemented when about 20 percent
         of the proposed project is completed.

Impact 2 – The Project would add more than 10 peak hour trips to the northbound approach (critical
approach) at the Gilman Street/Eastshore Highway intersection (#2B), would contribute to LOS F operations
on the northbound approach at the intersection during both AM and PM peak hours, and would meet the
California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant under the Pipeline Plus Project scenario, causing a significant
impact based on City of Berkeley thresholds.

         Mitigation Measure 2: Implement Mitigation Measure 1. With implementation of this mitigation
         measure, this impact would be reduced to a less-than-significant level.

Impact 3 – The addition of Project traffic would increase the average delay by more than two seconds at
the Sixth Street/University Avenue intersection (#12) and degrade intersection operations from LOS D to




                                                                                                           4
               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017



LOS E during the PM peak hour under the Pipeline Plus Project scenario, causing a significant impact based
on City of Berkeley thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 3: There are no feasible improvements that can be implemented within the
        available right-of-way at the Sixth Street/University Avenue intersection (#12). Therefore, the impact
        is significant and unavoidable. This finding is consistent with the 1900 Fourth Street Project Draft
        EIR (November 2016), and the West Berkeley Project EIR (February 2012).



 0.5         CUMULATIVE (2040) CONDITIONS

The addition of project traffic as compared to the Cumulative (2040) No Project condition is expected to
result in the following significant impacts:


Impact 4 – The addition of Project traffic would increase the volume-to-capacity ratio by more than 0.01 at
the Gilman Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#1), which would operate at LOS F during both AM
and PM peak hours under the Cumulative Plus Project scenario, causing a significant impact based on City
of Berkeley thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 4: Implement a Transportation Demand Management (TDM) Plan to reduce
        the automobile traffic and parking demand generated by the Project. Potential strategies that may
        be considered include:

             a. Either coordinate with the existing West Berkeley Shuttle or provide a new shuttle service
                between the Project site and BART.
             b. Provide bike lockers, showers, and personal lockers on-site to encourage bicycling to the
                site; encourage tenants to provide shared bicycles that employees can use during the day
                for errands
             c. Encourage a local car share company (City Car Share, ZIP Car, etc.) to locate a car share pod
                at the Project site or in close proximity to the site to provide an option for employees who
                may need a car during the day for meetings/errands but do not need a car for the commute
                trip
             d. Coordinate with City of Berkeley, and/or other regional agencies to allow installation of a
                BikeShare station near the Project site
             e. Provide preferential carpool parking
             f. Provide full or partial transit subsidy to Project employees
             g. Provide pre-tax commuter benefits for Project employees
             h. Regularly distribute information on non-automobile commuting options

        It is expected that implementing TDM strategies would reduce the Project trip generation and the
        magnitude of this and other identified impacts. The particular TDM strategies that would be


                                                                                                            5
              Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
              Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
              March 2017



        implemented at the Project site are currently not known. Therefore, the effectiveness of a TDM
        program cannot be quantified at this time and it is not known if a TDM program would reduce this
        and other identified impacts to a less-than-significant level.

        There are no feasible improvements that can be implemented within the available right-of-way at
        the Gilman Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#1). Therefore, the impact is significant and
        unavoidable.

Impact 5 – The addition of Project traffic would increase the volume-to-capacity ratio by more than 0.01 at
the Gilman Street/Eastbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#2), which would operate at LOS F during both AM
and PM peak hours under the Cumulative Plus Project scenario, causing a significant impact based on City
of Berkeley thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 5: There are no feasible improvements that can be implemented within the
        available right-of-way at the Gilman Street/Eastbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#2). Therefore, the
        impact is significant and unavoidable.

Impact 6 – The addition of Project traffic would increase the volume-to-capacity ratio by more than 0.01 at
the Sixth Street/Hearst Avenue intersection (#11) which would operate at LOS F during the AM peak hour
under the Cumulative Plus Project scenario, causing a significant impact based on City of Berkeley
thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 6: The significant impact can be mitigated by implementing signal timing and
        striping changes at intersection. Stripping modifications include restriping the southbound left-turn
        lane to a through/left-turn lane and the eastbound all-movement lane to a through/left-turn lane
        and right-turn pocket. This mitigation measure is consistent with the mitigation measure identified
        in the 1900 Fourth Street Project Draft EIR (November 2016). The Project shall contribute a fair share
        to the design and implementation of the intersection modifications. Implementation of this
        mitigation measure would improve the intersection operations to LOS C during the AM peak hour
        and LOS B during the PM peak hour, and would reduce the impact to less-than-significant.
        However, the provision of a shared left/though lane in the southbound direction may result in left-
        turning vehicles blocking through vehicles, which may increase safety conflicts for all travel modes.
        This mitigation is considered undesirable and infeasible because of these secondary impacts.
        Therefore, the impact is identified as significant and unavoidable.

Impact 7 – The addition of Project traffic would increase the average delay by more than three seconds at
the Sixth Street/University Avenue intersection (#12) and further exacerbate LOS E intersection operations
during the AM peak hour and increase the volume-to-capacity ratio by more than 0.01 at the intersection,


                                                                                                            6
               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017



which would operate at LOS F, during the PM peak hour under the Cumulative Plus Project scenario, causing
a significant impact based on City of Berkeley thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 7: There are no feasible improvements that can be implemented within the
        available right-of-way at the Sixth Street/University Avenue intersection (#12). Therefore, the impact
        is significant and unavoidable. This finding is consistent with the 1900 Fourth Street Project Draft
        EIR (November 2016), and the West Berkeley Project EIR (February 2012).

Impact 8 – The Project would add for than 10 peak hour trips to the eastbound approach (critical approach)
at the Sixth Street/Bancroft Way intersection (#13), cause the eastbound approach of the intersection to
operate at LOS F during the PM peak hour, and would meet the California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant
under the Cumulative Plus Project scenario, causing a significant impact based on City of Berkeley
thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 8: Signalize the Sixth Street/Bancroft Way intersection and coordinate signal
        timings with the adjacent intersections on Sixth and Seventh Streets. Implementation of this
        mitigation measure would improve the intersection operations to LOS A during both AM and PM
        peak hours and would reduce the impact to less-than-significant. The Project shall pay for the
        design and implementation of these improvements. It is estimated that this impact would be
        triggered and the mitigation measure would need to be implemented when about 15 percent of
        the proposed project is completed.



 0.6          SITE ACCESS, CIRCULATION, AND PARKING

Based on a review of the Project site and current surrounding conditions, the following are recommended
to improve multi-modal access and circulation for the proposed Project:

       Convert the Second Street/Addison Street intersection to all-way stop controlled operations.
       Prohibit gates or other controls at both Project driveways.
       Ensure adequate sight distance at both project driveways by maintaining the current on-street
        prohibition adjacent to the project driveway on Addison Street and prohibiting on-street parking
        between the project driveway and the railroad tracks along the project frontage on Bancroft Way.
       Identify location and amount of long-term bicycle parking for employees and provide controlled
        access for increased security.
       Provide short-term bicycle parking for visitors near each building entrance
       Provide on-site amenities, such as shower and locker facilities, and an on-site bicycle repair station




                                                                                                            7
               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017



       Identify on-site routes to connect the bicycle parking facilities with the surrounding street network
        (Either the internal project streets should be designed to accommodate bicycles or provide separate
        off-street paths).
       Construct sidewalks along the project frontage on Bancroft Way and Bolivar Drive.
       Identify pedestrian paths within the site to connect the project buildings, parking facilities, and the
        adjacent sidewalk network to each other along the pedestrian desire lines (i.e., shortest walking
        paths) with minimal potential conflicts with automobiles.

The proposed 878 parking spaces under Scheme 1 would be 46 spaces greater than required by the City
Code. The proposed 803 parking spaces under Scheme 2 would be one space greater than required by the
City Code.




                                                                                                             8
                 Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
                 Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
                 March 2017




1.0          INTRODUCTION

This report presents an analysis of the impacts of the proposed Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan (Project).
The Project site is located in West Berkeley adjacent to Berkeley Aquatic Park. The Project would consist of
up to approximately 475,000 square feet of R&D space in the block bounded by Addison Street to the
north, railroad tracks to the east, Bancroft Way to the south, and Bolivar Drive to the west. The existing site
consists of R&D uses (Plexxikon) to the north (approximately 30,000 square feet) and a soil yard (American
Soil) to the south. Plexxikon has four driveways: one on Bolivar Drive and three on Addison Street; the center
driveway on Addison Street (aligned with Second Street) is currently inactive. The soil yard has one driveway
on Bancroft Way.

Figure 1          Project Site and Study Locationsshows the location of the Project site and study
intersections.



 1.1         REPORT ORGANIZATION

This report is divided into the following six chapters:

            Chapter 1 – Introduction describes the analysis methods used for the transportation impact
             assessment of the proposed Project. This chapter also includes the significance criteria for
             determining Project impacts.

            Chapter 2 – Existing Conditions describes the existing conditions in the vicinity of the Project
             site, including the existing roadway network, traffic operations, transit, and bicycle and
             pedestrian circulation.

            Chapter 3 – Project Transportation Characteristics describes the estimated number of trips
             generated by the Project, and the projected trip distribution and assignment of Project trips.

            Chapter 4 – Pipeline Analysis describes the traffic operations under Pipeline No Project and
             Pipeline Plus Project conditions.

            Chapter 5 – Cumulative (2040) Analysis describes the 2040 Cumulative traffic operations
             for No Project and Plus Project scenarios.

            Chapter 6 – Access, Circulation, and Parking evaluates the access and circulation of all travel
             modes, and parking for the proposed project.

 1.2         ANALYSIS METHODOLOGY

Intersection operations are described using the term “Level of Service” (LOS). LOS is a qualitative description
of traffic operations from the vehicle driver perspective and consists of the delay experienced by the driver
at the intersection. It ranges from LOS A, with no congestion and little delay, to LOS F, with excessive
congestion and delays. Different methods are used to assess signalized and unsignalized (stop-controlled)
intersections.


1.2.1        SIGNALIZED INTERSECTIONS

Signalized intersection operations are evaluated using the method provided in the 2010 Highway Capacity
Manual (HCM). This method uses intersection characteristics to estimate average control delay and then
assigns a LOS value. Control delay is defined as the delay associated with deceleration, stopping, moving
up in the queue, and acceleration experienced by drivers at a signalized intersection. Table 1 provides
descriptions of various LOS and the corresponding ranges of delays for signalized intersections.


1.2.2        UNSIGNALIZED INTERSECTIONS

All-way stop-controlled and side-street stop-controlled intersection operations are also analyzed using the
2010 HCM. Delay is calculated for movements that are controlled by a stop sign or that must yield the right-
of-way. This method defines operations by average control delay per vehicle (measured in seconds) for each
stop-controlled movement. This incorporates delay associated with deceleration, acceleration, stopping,
and moving up in the queue. For side-street stop-controlled intersections, the movement or approach with
the highest delay is reported, as well as average intersection delay. Table 1 summarizes the LOS ranges for
unsignalized intersections. They are lower than the delay ranges for signalized intersections because drivers
generally tolerate more delay at signals.

Roundabout intersections are evaluated using the method provided in the HCM 6th Edition. This method
calculated delay for all movements that must yield the right-of-way to circulating traffic in the roundabout,
and is defined similarly as stop-controlled intersections. Both average intersection and the approach with
the highest delay are reported. LOS ranges for roundabouts are the same as stop-controlled intersections,
as summarized in Table 1.




                                                                                                            11
               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017

                                                                 good signal progression and/or short cycle lengths. More
   Operations with       >10.0 and                  >10.0 and
                                          B                      vehicles stop than with LOS A, causing higher levels of
    minor delay.           15.0                      20.0
                                                                 average delay. An occasional approach phase is fully
                                                                 utilized.

                                                                 Stable Operation or Acceptable Delays:
                                                                 Higher delays resulting from fair signal progression and/ or
  Operations with        >15.0 and                  >20.0 and
                                          C                      longer cycle lengths. Drivers begin having to wait through
  moderate delays.         25.0                      35.0
                                                                 more than one red light. Most drivers feel somewhat
                                                                 restricted.

                           35.0                      55.0      high volume to capacity ratios. Many vehicles stop. Drivers

                                                                 the limit of acceptable delay. High delays indicate poor
  Operations with

                           50.0                      80.0      capacity ratios. Individual cycle failures are frequent

Source: Highway Capacity Manual, Transportation Research Board, 2010.




                                                                                                                                12
                Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
                Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
                March 2017



1.2.3       ANALYSIS TOOLS

The Synchro 9 Software was used to estimate delay and LOS for all signalized, all-way stop-controlled, and
side-street stop-controlled study intersections. Synchro uses the equations provided in 2010 HCM to
calculate control delay. These equations use intersection characteristics, such as vehicle and pedestrian
volumes, lane geometry, and signal phasings, as inputs in estimating control delay.

The Sidra 7 Software was used to estimate delay and LOS for roundabout controlled study intersections.
Sidra 7 uses the equations provided in the HCM 6th Edition to calculate control delay.



1.3         SIGNIFICANCE CRITERIA

This section describes the thresholds of significance used to determine if a Project would cause a significant
impact. For the purposes of this analysis, the following intersection LOS thresholds of significance are used
based on the city of Berkeley.

An impact is considered significant if:

           At a signalized, roundabout, or all-way stop-controlled intersection operations degrade from
            LOS D to LOS E or worse and more than a two-second increase in delay; or

           At a signalized, roundabout, or all-way stop-controlled intersection, more than a three-second
            increase in delay at intersections operating at LOS E without and with the Project; or

           At a signalized, roundabout, or all-way stop-controlled intersection, operations degrade from
            LOS E to LOS F and more than a three-second increase in delay; or

           At a signalized, roundabout, or all-way stop-controlled intersection operating at LOS F without
            the Project, a change in the volume-to-capacity (v/c) ratio of more than 0.01.

           At an unsignalized intersection, the addition of Project-related traffic causes:
            o    the critical approach to operate at LOS F; and
            o    the intersection meets peak hour traffic volume signal warrants; and
            o    minimum of 10 peak-hour vehicles added to a critical movement; and
            o    and no alternative routes are available.




                                                                                                           13
               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017




2.0          EXISTING CONDITIONS

This chapter describes existing transportation conditions for the Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan site.



 2.1         EXISTING ROADWAY NETWORK

The regional and local roadways serving the Project site are described below.


 2.1.1       REGIONAL ROADWAYS

Interstate 80/580 (I-80/I-580) provides access around and beyond the San Francisco Bay Area. Between
Emeryville and Albany, I-80 shares the same roadway as I-580, with I-580 eventually turning west towards
Marin while I-80 turns east towards Sacramento. Within the Project study area, I-80 and I-580 are oriented
in a north-south direction and provide five lanes of travel in each direction. Access from I-80/I-580 to the
Project site is provided through the interchange at University Avenue. I-80/I-580 operates at capacity during
the peak commute hours. I-80/I-580 has an Average Annual Daily Traffic (AADT) of 262,000 vehicles at the
University Avenue interchange (Caltrans, 2015).

San Pablo Avenue (SR 123) is a divided, four-lane, north-south major street that extends between Rodeo in
the north and 1Sixth Street in Downtown Oakland in the south. The divided roadway provides a center
median and left-turn pockets at major intersections. San Pablo Avenue provides sidewalks and parallel
parking on both sides of the street near the Project site. San Pablo Avenue has an AADT of 19,300 at
University Avenue (Caltrans, 2015).

 2.1.2       LOCAL ROADWAYS

Second Street is a two-lane, north-south roadway that provides some on-street parking on both sides of the
street. There are limited pedestrian facilities on this roadway and no bicycle facilities near the Project site.

Fourth Street is a two-lane, north-south roadway that provides some on-street parking on both sides of the
street. There are sidewalks on this roadway near the study area. Fourth Street between Hearst Avenue and
Channing Way is a designated bicycle route.

Sixth Street is a north-south collector with one lane in each direction in the vicinity of the Project that
generally provides on-street parking and sidewalks along both sides of the street. There are designated turn
pockets at major intersections along the street.


                                                                                                              14
                 Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
                 Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
                 March 2017



Seventh Street is a two-lane, north-south collector extending between Harrison Street in the north and
Folger Avenue in the south. It generally provides on-street parking and sidewalks on both sides.

Addison Street is a two-lane, east-west roadway that generally provides on-street parking and sidewalks
along both sides of the street. Addison Street between Bolivar Drive and Fourth Street is a designated
bicycle route.

Bancroft Way is a two-lane, east-west roadway that generally provides on-street parking and sidewalks
along both sides of the street. Bancroft Way between Bolivar Drive and Ninth Street is a designated bicycle
route.

Bolivar Drive is a two-lane, north-south private roadway adjacent to Berkeley Aquatic Park between Addison
Street and Bancroft Way. Bolivar Drive is also a designated bicycle route that provides pedestrian/bicycle
access to the Eastshore Pedestrian Overcrossing. Trucks are prohibited on Bolivar Drive.

Dwight Way is a two-lane, east-west collector traversing from the Berkeley Aquatic Park in the west and to
the University of California, Berkeley campus in the east. It provides on-street parking and sidewalks on
both sides of the street. East of Martin Luther King Jr. Way, Dwight Way is a two-lane one-way eastbound
street.

Hearst Avenue is a two-lane, east-west roadway that generally provides on-street parking and sidewalks
along both sides of the street. Hearst Avenue between Fourth and Fifth Streets is a designated bicycle route.

Gilman Street is a two-lane, east-west roadway that provides access to I-80/580. It generally provides on-
street parking and sidewalks along both sides of the street. The segment of Gilman Street between I-80/580
and San Pablo Avenue has a dedicated bicycle lane. The segment west of San Pablo Avenue is a designated
bicycle route.

University Avenue is a four-lane, east-west arterial between downtown Berkeley in the east and I-80/580
and the Berkeley Marina in the west. University Avenue is a divided roadway with raised medians and left-
turn pockets at major intersections. University Avenue is an elevated structure between Sixth Street and just
west of the I-80/580 interchange, with one-way frontage roads on both sides of the roadway between the
railroad tracks and Fifth Street.




                                                                                                          15
               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017




 2.2         TRAFFIC OPERATIONS ANALYSIS

This study analyzes existing traffic operations during typical weekday AM and PM peak hours at the
following 15 intersections in the vicinity of the Project:

 1.   Gilman Street/I-80 Westbound Ramps/West                8.    Fourth Street/Hearst Avenue
      Frontage Road                                          9.    Fourth Street/Addison Street
 2.   Gilman Street/I-80 Eastbound Ramps/                    10.   Fourth Street/Bancroft Way
      Eastshore Highway                                      11.   Sixth Street/Hearst Avenue
 3.   Bolivar Drive/Addison Street                           12.   Sixth Street/University Avenue
 4.   Bolivar Drive/Bancroft Way                             13.   Sixth Street/Bancroft Way
 5.   Second Street/Hearst Avenue                            14.   Seventh Street/Dwight Way
 6.   Second Street/I-80 Eastbound Off-Ramp                  15.   San Pablo Avenue/University Avenue
 7.   Second Street/Addison Street

These intersections were selected for analysis because they are most likely to be affected by the proposed
Project. Figure 1 shows the location of the study intersections.


 2.2.1       EXISTING INTERSECTION VOLUMES

AM and PM peak period (7:00 to 9:00 AM and 4:00 to 6:00 PM) intersection turning movement, pedestrian,
and bicycle volumes were collected on January 27, 2016 at intersections 1 and 2, February 2, 2016 at
intersections 8, 11, 12, and 15, September 14, 2016 at intersections 3, 4, 7, 9, 10, 13, and 14, and January 24,
2017 at intersections 5 and 6. These time periods were selected because the trips generated by the
proposed Project during the peak periods, in combination with background traffic, are expected to
represent typical worst traffic conditions.

Figure 2 shows the existing AM and PM peak hour intersection vehicle volumes and the lane configurations
and controls at the study intersections. Figure 3 shows the existing AM and PM peak hour bicycle and
pedestrian volumes. Appendix A presents the detailed count sheets for the study intersections.


2.2.2        EXISTING INTERSECTION OPERATIONS

Based on the volumes, intersection controls, and roadway configurations presented on Figure 2, Fehr &
Peers calculated the AM and PM peak hour LOS at the study intersections using the methodologies
presented in Chapter 1. Table 2 summarizes existing weekday AM and PM peak hour intersection LOS
analysis results. Appendix B provides the detailed calculation work sheets.

1. Average intersection delay and LOS based on the 2010 HCM method, unless noted. Average delay is reported for signalized
     intersections. Average and worst-approach delays, respectively, are reported for side-street stop controlled intersections.
2. Estimated based on 2010 HCM delay thresholds.
3. Average intersection delay and LOS based on the HCM 2000 method because the intersection cannot be correctly evaluated in
     the 2010 HCM.
4. When there is rail activity in the area, intersection operations are worse than shown in this table.
Source: Fehr & Peers, 2017.

                  Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
                  Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
                  March 2017



As shown in the table, the stop-controlled movements at the Gilman Interchange (intersections 1 and 2)
operate at LOS F during both AM and PM peak hours, and signalized Sixth Street/University Avenue
intersection (#15) currently operates at LOS E during the PM peak hour. All other study intersections operate
at LOS D or better during both AM and PM peak hours.

The peak hour traffic signal warrant was evaluated for the thirteen unsignalized study intersections. Four of
the thirteen intersections (1A, 1B, 2A, 2B), would meet the California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant under
the existing conditions. Appendix C provides the signal warrant worksheets.



    2.3        EXISTING TRANSIT SERVICES

The Berkeley Aquatic Park is served by BART, AC Transit, and Amtrak California. Figure 4 shows the transit
routes in the vicinity of the Project site. Each transit service is described below.


    2.3.1      BART

BART provides regional commuter rail transit in Alameda, Contra Costa, San Francisco, and San Mateo
counties. Currently, BART trains operate on weekdays from 4:00 AM to 12:00 AM, on Saturdays from 6:00
AM to 12:00 AM, and on Sundays from 8:00 AM to 12:00 AM. The nearest BART stations to the Project site
are the North Berkeley BART station located about 1.5 miles northeast of the Project site and the Downtown
Berkeley BART station located about two miles east of the Project site.

Both the North Berkeley and the Downtown Berkeley BART Stations are served by the Richmond-Fremont
and Richmond-Daly City/Millbrae lines. Other destinations in the BART system can be reached by
transferring at stations in Oakland. Typically, both Stations are served by a train between every eight minutes
during peak weekday commute periods and every 20 minutes on weekends and holidays. The North
Berkeley BART station had average weekday entries and exists of approximately 8,900 passengers and the
Downtown Berkeley BART station had average weekday entries and exits of approximately 22,800
passengers in January 20171.




1   Bay Area Rapid Transit 2016 Monthly Ridership Reports http://www.bart.gov/about/reports/ridership.

                  March 2017



    2.3.2      AC TRANSIT

Local bus service serving Berkeley Aquatic Park is provided by AC Transit, the public transportation authority
for western Alameda and Contra Costa counties. As shown on Figure 4, Berkeley Aquatic Park is served by
several AC Transit bus routes, connecting the Project site to other neighborhoods within Berkeley, the
adjacent cities of Albany, Emeryville, Oakland, and San Francisco. Table 3 describes the AC Transit bus
routes serving the Project area.

The nearest bus stops to the Berkeley Aquatic Park are on University Avenue at the Berkeley Amtrak station,
about 0.1 miles north of the Project site, and on San Pablo Avenue at University Avenue, about 0.6 miles
east of the Project site.


    2.3.3      AMTRAK

Amtrak provides regional rail transit for intercity commuters in both northern and southern California, with
select service to Nevada. Amtrak’s Capitol Corridor route operates between San Jose and Sacramento.


The Berkeley station is located under the University Avenue overpass, about 0.1 miles northwest of the
Project site. There are 15 daily weekday departures and arrivals and 11 daily weekend departures and arrivals
at the Berkeley Station.2 In FY2015, the station served nearly 140,000 rail passengers.3 The Amtrak station is
also served directly by AC Transit bus routes 51B and 802, with additional bus service nearby. While the
station is unstaffed, there are basic station amenities include outside seating, and automobile and bicycle
parking.




2   Amtrak Capitol Corridor Schedule https://www.amtrak.com/ccurl/119/533/Capitol-Corridor-Schedule-082216.pdf
3   Amtrak Fact Sheet, Fiscal Year 2015 https://www.amtrak.com/pdf/factsheets/CALIFORNIA15.pdf

2.4          EXISTING PEDESTRIAN AND BICYCLE CIRCULATION

Within the Project study area, most non-residential and all residential streets provide sidewalks. Sidewalks
adjacent to the site along Addison Street currently range between seven and 11 feet wide. No sidewalks are
provided along Bolivar Drive between Addison Street and Bancroft Way, and along Bancroft Way between
the railroad tracks and Bolivar Drive. Second Street between Addison Street and University Avenue provides
sidewalks without curbs which results in automobiles parking in the sidewalk and blocking the pedestrian
path.

Adjacent to the Project site, high visibility crosswalks and curb bulb-outs are provided along Addison Street.
Signalized intersections in the vicinity of Berkeley Aquatic Park provide curb ramps and pedestrian signal
heads. Marked crosswalks are provided at most unsignalized intersections near the Project site.

Based on the City of Berkeley Bicycle Master Plan Public Draft (October 2016), bicycle facilities can be
classified into several types, including:


   Bicycle Paths (Class I) – These facilities are located off-street and may serve both bicyclists and
    pedestrians. They provide complete right-of-way to cycling, walking, and other non-motorized forms
    of transportation.

   Bicycle Lanes (Class II) – These facilities provide a dedicated area for bicyclists within the paved street
    width through the use of striping and appropriate signage.

   Bicycle Routes (Class III) – These facilities are found along streets that do not provide sufficient width
    for dedicated bicycle lanes. The street is then designated as a bicycle route through the use of signage
    informing drivers to expect bicyclists. They are only suitable for low-traffic streets with slow travel
    speeds. Arterial Bike Routes are generally along collector and arterial streets when bicycle lanes are
    infeasible.

   Separated Bikeways (Class IV) – These are separated and protected bikeways where a type of barrier,
    usually curbs, bollards, or parking isles, separate the bike lane from the vehicular flow of traffic. These
    are also known as cycle tracks.

   Bicycle Boulevards – These facilities are installed along residential streets with low traffic volumes and
    prioritize bicycle travel. Assignment of right-of-way to the route, traffic calming measures and bicycle
    traffic signal actuation are used to prioritize through-trips for bicycles.

Figure 5 identifies existing and proposed bicycle facilities in the study area.

               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017



A mix of bicycle paths, bicycle boulevards, and bicycle lanes provide direct access to nearby commercial
and business areas in Berkeley as well as the Berkeley Amtrak station. Addison Street adjacent to the Project
site and Fourth Street just east of the Project site are identified as a Class III bicycle route. Existing bicycle
boulevards near the Project site include Virginia Street and Channing Way in the east-west direction and
Ninth Street in the north-south direction. The Class I Eastshore Pedestrian Overcrossing which connects to
the Berkeley Marina is just northwest of the Project site.

The City of Berkeley Bicycle Master Plan Public Draft identifies Addison Street a proposed bicycle boulevard
and University Avenue and San Pablo Avenue as proposed Class IV cycletrack.



2.5          EXISTING SITE-GENERATED TRAFFIC

The existing site consists of R&D uses (Plexxikon) to the north (approximately 30,000 square feet) and a soil
yard (American Soil) to the south. The R&D use has four driveways: one on Bolivar Drive and three on
Addison Street; the center driveway on Addison Street (aligned with Second Street) is currently inactive. The
soil yard has one driveway on Bancroft Way. Peak period morning (7:00 to 9:00 AM) and evening (4:00 to
6:00 PM) counts were collected at the four active driveways in September 2015,4 to estimate the trip
generation of the existing site. Table 4 presents the trip generation for the hour with the highest trip
generation within the peak period at the existing site.

Since trucks are larger and operate slower than passenger vehicles, Fehr & Peers used a passenger car
equivalent (PCE) ratio of 2.0 per the Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) 2010 to convert truck trips to
passenger vehicle trips. As shown in Table 4, the existing site generates 39 AM peak hour and 36 PM peak
hour PCE trips. About three-quarters of the trips generated by Plexxikon and all trips generated by the
American Soil are driving trips.




4Counts were collected on September 23, 2015 for the west driveway on Addison Street; counts for the other three
driveways were collected on September 15, 2015.

3.0         PROJECT TRANSPORTATION CHARACTERISTICS

This section describes the proposed Project, its transportation characteristics, and summarizes the effects
of the proposed Project under Existing plus Project conditions.



 3.1        PROJECT DESCRIPTION

The proposed Project would consist of several buildings providing up to approximately 475,000 square feet
of R&D space in the block bounded by Addison Street to the north, railroad tracks to the east, Bancroft Way
to the south, and Bolivar Drive to the west. There are currently two site plan schemes for the proposed
Project, as shown on Figures 6A and 6B. Under both schemes, automobile access to the site would be
provided through full-access driveways on Addison Street opposite Second Street and on Bancroft Way
between Bolivar Drive and the railroad tracks. Neither scheme would provide direct access between the
Project site and Bolivar Drive, which is a planned Class III Bicycle Facility. Internal streets would provide
access between the driveways, Project buildings, and parking facilities. The Project would provide about 575
parking spaces.



 3.2        TRIP GENERATION

Trip generation is the process of estimating the number of vehicles that would likely access the Project site.
Fehr & Peers estimated the trip generation for the proposed Project using the data and methodology
published by the Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) in the Trip Generation Manual, Ninth Edition.
However, ITE data are primarily based on data collected at single-use suburban sites. These defining
characteristics limit their applicability to developments, such as the proposed Project, which is in a more
walkable urban setting near local and regional transit service.

To account for trips to and from the Project site that would made by non-automobile modes, a modal
reduction was applied to the raw ITE trip generation. The modal reduction is based on census data for the
Project area. The 2010 5-year American Community Survey shows that about 17 percent of workers in the
Project census tract travel to and from work by non-automobile modes. Therefore, the AM and PM peak
hour trip generation for the Project was reduced by approximately seventeen percent.

Table 5 summarizes the trip generation for the proposed Project based on the ITE methodology and
accounts for the non-automobile trips and trips generated by the existing site uses. It is estimated that the
proposed Project would generate about 2,770 daily, and 379 AM and 363 PM peak hour net new trips.

          PM Peak Hour: Ln(T) = 0.83*Ln(X)+1.06 (15% in, 85% out)

3.1            TRIP DISTRIBUTION AND ASSIGNMENT

Trip distribution is defined as the directions of approach and departure that vehicles would use to arrive at
and depart from the Project site. Trip distribution for the proposed site is based on the trip distribution
presented in the West Berkeley Circulation Master Plan (WBCMP), with modifications to reflect the Project
location, and traffic patterns in the area. Figure 7 presents the resulting trip distribution for the Project site.

Since the site access points are the same between the two site plans and internal circulation is similar, both
site plans would have the same trip assignment. Using the trip distribution presented on Figure 7, Project
trips were assigned to the roadway network. Figures 8A and 8B show the resulting AM and PM peak hour
trip assignment by roadway segment under the proposed Project. The study intersections are either
adjacent to the site, signalized intersections that the proposed Project would add 50 or more peak hour
trips to, or other intersections likely to be affected by the proposed Project. Figure 9 presents the peak
hour Project trips for the proposed Project at the study intersections.

               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017




4.0          PIPELINE ANALYSIS

This section summarizes traffic operations under Pipeline No Project and Pipeline Plus Project conditions.



        4.1          PIPELINE PROJECTS

The Pipeline scenarios account for traffic generated by the following proposed and approved Projects in
the vicinity of the Project site, which are likely to be completed in the near future:

       2200 Fifth Street, a residential development
       1900 Fourth Street, a mixed-use development
       1919 Fourth Street, a mixed-use development
       2001 Fourth Street, a mixed-use development
       1050 Parker Street, a medical office development
       1201 San Pablo Avenue, a mixed-use development
       1500 San Pablo Avenue, a mixed-use development
       2100 San Pablo Avenue, a mixed-use development
       2527 San Pablo Avenue, a mixed-use development
       2720 San Pablo Avenue, a mixed-use development
       2747 San Pablo Avenue, a mixed use development
       2748 San Pablo Avenue, a mixed use development
       2013 Second Street, a mixed use development
       800 University Avenue, a mixed-use development
       824 University Avenue, a mixed-use development

Appendix D provides the land uses and trip generation for these developments. Traffic generated by each
pipeline Project was distributed to the surrounding transportation network and assigned to the study
intersections based on the Project environmental document or transportation impact analysis (TIA), if
available. For the pipeline Projects without an environmental document or TIA, the trip distribution and
assignment from the environmental document or TIA for nearby pipeline Projects were used.



4.2          PIPELINE NO PROJECT CONDITIONS

Figure 10 shows the Pipeline traffic volumes, which consists of traffic volumes under Existing No Project
conditions (Figure 2) plus traffic generated by the approved uses of the Pipeline Projects described above.
This analysis assumes no roadway modifications at the study intersections under this scenario.

               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017



Table 6 summarizes the Pipeline Plus Project intersection LOS analysis results. Appendix B provides the
detailed calculation work sheets. As shown in the table, the following intersections are projected to operate
at overall LOS E or F under Pipeline No Project Conditions:

       The side-street stop controlled northbound approach at the Gilman Street/West Frontage Road
        intersection (#1A) would operate at LOS F during the AM peak hour.
       The side-street stop controlled southbound approach at the Gilman Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps
        intersection (#1B) would operate at LOS F during both AM and PM peak hours.
       The side-street stop controlled northbound approach at the Gilman Street/Eastbound I-80 Ramps
        intersection (#2A) would operate at LOS F during PM peak hour.
       The side-street stop controlled northbound approach at the Gilman Street/Eastshore Highway
        intersection (#2B) will operate at LOS F during both AM and PM peak hours.
       The signalized San Pablo Avenue/University Avenue intersection (#15) will operate at LOS E during
        the PM peak hour.

The peak hour traffic signal warrant was evaluated for the thirteen unsignalized study intersections. Five of
the thirteen intersections (1A, 1B, 2A, and 2B), would meet the California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant
under the Pipeline No Project scenario. Appendix C provides the signal warrant worksheets.



4.3         PIPELINE PLUS PROJECT CONDITIONS

Figure 11 shows the Pipeline Plus Project traffic volumes, which consists of traffic volumes under Pipeline
No Project conditions (Figure 10) plus traffic generated by the Project (Figure 9). This analysis assumes no
roadway modifications at the study intersections under this scenario.

Table 6 summarizes the Pipeline Plus Project intersection LOS analysis results. Appendix B provides the
detailed calculation work sheets. As shown in the table, the following intersections are projected to operate
at overall LOS E or F under Pipeline Plus Project Conditions:

       The side-street stop controlled northbound approach at the Gilman Street/West Frontage Road
        intersection (#1A) would operate at LOS F during the AM peak hour.
       The side-street stop controlled southbound approach at the Gilman Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps
        intersection (#1B) would operate at LOS F during both AM and PM peak hours.
       The side-street stop controlled northbound approach at the Gilman Street/Eastbound I-80 Ramps
        intersection (#2A) would operate at LOS F during PM peak hour.
       The side-street stop controlled northbound approach at the Gilman Street/Eastshore Highway
        intersection (#2B) would operate at LOS F during both AM and PM peak hours.
       The side-street stop controlled southbound approach at the Second Street/Addison Street
        intersection (#7) would operate at LOS E during the AM peak hour.
       The signalized Sixth Street/University Avenue intersection (#12) would operate at LOS E during
        the PM peak hour.

Intersections operating at unacceptable levels are shown in bold.
1. SSSC = Side-Street Stop Controlled; AWSC = All-Way Stop Controlled
2. Average intersection delay and LOS based on the 2010 HCM method unless noted. Average delay is reported for signalized
     intersections. Average and worst-approach delays, respectively, are reported for side-street stop controlled intersections.
3. Estimated based on 2010 HCM delay thresholds.
4. Average intersection delay and LOS based on the HCM 2000 method because the intersection cannot be correctly evaluated
     in the 2010 HCM
5. When there is rail activity in the area, intersection operations are worse than shown in this table.
Source: Fehr & Peers, 2017.

       The signalized San Pablo Avenue/University Avenue intersection (#15) would operate at LOS E
        during the PM peak hour.

The peak hour traffic signal warrant was evaluated for the thirteen unsignalized study intersections under
Pipeline Plus Project conditions. Five of the thirteen intersections (1A, 1B, 2A, 2B, and 13), would meet the
California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant under the Pipeline Plus Project scenario. Appendix C provides
the signal warrant worksheets.



4.4         PIPELINE CONDITION PROJECT IMPACTS AND MITAGATIONS

The Pipeline Plus Project analysis results were compared to the Pipeline No Project Conditions results using
the significance criteria summarized in Chapter 1. The proposed Project would not cause a significant impact
at the following intersections that operate at LOS E or LOS F under Pipeline Plus Project conditions:
       The side-street stop controlled Gilman Street/West Frontage Road intersection (#1A) would operate
        at LOS F during the AM peak hour under Pipeline Conditions regardless of the Project. However,
        the proposed Project would add less than 10 peak hour trips to a critical movement at the
        intersection. Therefore the impact at this intersections is less-than-significant.
       The side-street stop controlled Gilman Street/Eastbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#2A) would
        operate at LOS F during the AM peak hour under Pipeline Conditions regardless of the Project.
        However, the proposed Project would add less than 10 peak hour trips to a critical movement at
        the intersection. Therefore the impact at this intersections is less-than-significant.
       The side-street stop controlled Sixth Street/Bancroft Way intersection (#13) would meet the peak
        hour signal warrant under Pipeline Plus Project conditions. However, the proposed project would
        not cause a significant impact at this intersection because the side-street stop controlled approach
        would not operate at LOS F
       The signalized San Pablo Avenue/University Avenue intersection (#15) which would operate at LOS
        E during the PM peak hour under Pipeline Conditions regardless of the Project. However, the
        addition of Project traffic would not increase average intersection delay by more than three
        seconds. Therefore the impact at this intersections is less-than-significant.

The Project would result in the following significant impacts under Pipeline Plus Project Conditions:

Impact 1 – The Project would add more than 10 peak hour trips to the southbound approach (critical
approach) at the Gilman Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#1B), would contribute to LOS F
operations on the southbound approach at the intersection during both AM and PM peak hours, and would
meet the California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant under the Pipeline Plus Project scenario, causing a
significant impact based on City of Berkeley thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 1: The impact can be mitigated by implementing the planned improvements
        at the I-80 Gilman Street interchange, which consist of two roundabouts. With implementation of
        this mitigation measure, this impact would be reduced to a less-than-significant level. The Project


                                                                                                          43
               Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
               Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
               March 2017



        shall contribute a fair share to the design and implementation of these improvements, which is
        estimated to be about two percent. It is estimated that this impact would be triggered and the
        mitigation measure would need to be implemented when about 20 percent of the proposed project
        is completed.

Impact 2 – The Project would add more than 10 peak hour trips to the northbound approach (critical
approach) at the Gilman Street/Eastshore Highway intersection (#2B), would contribute to LOS F operations
on the northbound approach at the intersection during both AM and PM peak hours, and would meet the
California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant under the Pipeline Plus Project scenario, causing a significant
impact based on City of Berkeley thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 2: Implement Mitigation Measure 1. With implementation of this mitigation
        measure, this impact would be reduced to a less-than-significant level.

Impact 3 – The addition of Project traffic would increase the average delay by more than two seconds at
the Sixth Street/University Avenue intersection (#12) and degrade intersection operations from LOS D to
LOS E during the PM peak hour under the Pipeline Plus Project scenario, causing a significant impact based
on City of Berkeley thresholds.

        Mitigation Measure 3: There are no feasible improvements that can be implemented within the
        available right-of-way at the Sixth Street/University Avenue intersection (#12). Therefore, the impact
        is significant and unavoidable. This finding is consistent with the 1900 Fourth Street Project Draft
        EIR (November 2016), and the West Berkeley Project EIR (February 2012).




                                                                                                           44
                  Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan
                  Draft Transportation Impact Analysis
                  March 2017




5.0            CUMULATIVE (2040) ANALYSIS

This section summarizes traffic operations under Cumulative (2040) No Project and Cumulative (2040) Plus
Project conditions.



           5.1          CUMULATIVE (2040) NO PROJECT CONDITIONS

Traffic forecasts for the year 2040 were developed based on the results of the Alameda County
Transportation Commission (ACTC) Countywide Travel Demand Model. The most recent version of the ACTC
Model, released in in 2015, which reflects assumptions in residential and non-residential land use growth
consistent with ABAG Projections 2013 (i.e., Sustainable Community Strategies), served as the basis for
developing AM and PM peak hour intersection turning movement forecasts for the year 2040. The Model
land use database and roadway network were checked for accuracy in the vicinity of the Project. The AM
and PM peak hour roadway segment volumes forecasted by the ACTC Model for year 2040 were used to
develop 2040 turning movement forecasts at the study intersections. Figure 12 shows the Cumulative
(2040) No Project traffic volumes.

The Cumulative (2040) No Project analysis assumes the following roadway modifications:

          The side-street stop controlled Gilman Street/West Frontage Road (#1A) and Gilman
           Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps (#1B) intersections would be replaced with a five-legged
           roundabout.5
          The side-street stop controlled Gilman Street/Eastbound Ramps (#2A) and Gilman Street/Eastshore
           Highway (#2B) intersections would be replaced with a six-legged roundabout.

In addition, the 2040 analyses assume that simple signal timing parameters that do not require upgrades
to the signal equipment, consisting of amount of green time allocated to each intersection approach and/or
offsets, would be optimized at the signalized study intersections. This assumption reflects current practices
that incorporate basic signal timing changes into routine maintenance of the traffic signal system. It is
expected that retiming of signals in areas with the greatest need (e.g., major streets, areas with rapidly
shifting traffic patterns) would be prioritized as part of the regular ongoing maintenance of signal
equipment.

              Berkeley Aquatic Park Master Plan

Table 7 summarizes intersection operations at the study intersections under the Cumulative (2040) Plus
Project conditions. Appendix B provides the detailed calculation work sheets. As shown in the table, the
following intersections are projected to operate at LOS E or F under Cumulative No Project Conditions:

       The roundabout controlled Gilman Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#1) would operate
        at LOS F during both AM and PM peak hours.
       The roundabout controlled Gilman Street/Eastbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#2) would operate
        at LOS E during the AM peak hour and LOS F during the PM peak hour.
       The all-way stop controlled Second Street/Hearst Avenue intersection (#5) would operate at LOS E
        during the AM peak hour.
       The all-way stop controlled Fourth Street/Hearst Avenue intersection (#8) would operate at LOS E
        during the AM peak hour.
       The signalized Sixth Street/Hearst Avenue intersection (#11) would operate at LOS F during the AM
        peak hour.
       The signalized Sixth Street/University Avenue intersection (#12) would operate at LOS E during the
        AM peak hour and LOS F during the PM peak hour.
       The side-street stop controlled eastbound approach at the Sixth Street/Bancroft Way intersection
        (#13) would operate at LOS F during the PM peak hour.
       The signalized San Pablo Avenue/University Avenue intersection (#15) would operate at LOS F
        during both AM and PM peak hours.

The peak hour traffic signal warrant was evaluated for the nine stop-controlled study intersections. None of
the study intersections would meets the California MUTCD peak hour signal warrant under the Cumulative
No Project scenario. Appendix C provides the signal warrant worksheets.



        5.2         CUMULATIVE (2040) PLUS PROJECT CONDITIONS

Figure 13 shows the Cumulative (2040) Plus Project traffic volumes, which consists of traffic volumes under
Cumulative (2040) No Project conditions (Figure 10) plus the proposed Project traffic assignment (Figure 7).
This analysis assumes no roadway modifications at the study intersections under this scenario.

Table 7 summarizes intersection operations at the study intersections under the Cumulative (2040) Plus
Project conditions. Appendix B provides the detailed calculation work sheets. As shown in the table, the
following intersections are projected to operate at LOS E or F under Cumulative No Project Conditions:

       The roundabout controlled Gilman Street/Westbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#1) would operate
        at LOS F during both AM and PM peak hours.
       The roundabout controlled Gilman Street/Eastbound I-80 Ramps intersection (#2) would operate
        at LOS F during both AM and PM peak hours.
       The all-way stop controlled Second Street/Hearst Avenue intersection (#5) would operate at LOS E
        during the AM peak hour.
